s1.title: Introduction
s1.p: Jesktop applications ship in jars. The jar must contain a manifest that Jesktop can pick up on so that it know's what's inside the jar. Jesktop's manifest is placed in a directory called JESKTOP-INF inside the jar. The file name of the manifest is applications.xml and it is in XML format.

s1.title: A more complex example
s1.p: This example details four other concepts.

ol.li: Muliple apps in one jar - the application element is repeating.
Default applications - of use when an application is not being installed, merely run in situ inside it's jar.
Icons to represent apps - used when listing the app on the start menu or in a file-system view.
Application specific config files - the config for the app in question is specified elsewhere.

s1.title: Rules
s1.p: There are a number of rules to the use of this manifest.

ol.li: Targets are launchable. Each application entry is a separate launchable target. Multiple apps may share tha same code base and will be loaded via the same classloader so must be able to co-exist with ench other in one VM sharing static space.

Targets are launchable multiple times. Unless the single-instance="true" attrible has been specified the target may be launched multiple times. A classloading issue again in that static must be used carefully.

JComponent or JFrimble devived class The class that Jesktop instantiates must be a subclass of JComponent or JFrimble. JFrame is not allowed on this class. Use one of the alternative Frimble solutions instead.

s1.title: Interoperation with the normal jar manifest
s1.p: If you want to have an application that is dual mode in that it can run standalone as well as inside Jesktop, you'll want to have a META-INF/manifest.mf file that specifies the executable nature of the jar. This normal Java feature is completely supported.
